name: Minotaur
shortDescription: Bull-headed man imprisoned in the Labyrinth of Crete, offspring of Pasipha√´ and the Cretan Bull
fullDescription: The Minotaur (Greek: ŒúŒπŒΩœéœÑŒ±œÖœÅŒøœÇ, 'Bull of Minos') is one of the most iconic monsters in Greek mythology‚Äîa creature with the head of a bull and the body of a man. Born from the unnatural union of Queen Pasipha√´ of Crete and a magnificent white bull sent by Poseidon, the Minotaur was the product of divine punishment for King Minos's failure to sacrifice the bull as promised. Named Asterion ('starry one'), the creature's existence shamed the royal family. King Minos commissioned the master craftsman Daedalus to construct an elaborate Labyrinth beneath his palace at Knossos, an inescapable maze where the Minotaur could be hidden from the world. Every nine years (or annually, depending on the source), Athens was forced to send seven young men and seven young women as tribute to be devoured by the Minotaur, until the hero Theseus volunteered, navigated the Labyrinth with the aid of Minos's daughter Ariadne and her thread, and slew the beast. The Minotaur represents the bestial nature hidden within civilization, the consequences of broken vows to the gods, and the monster born from unnatural desire.

mythologyContexts.symbolism: The Minotaur represents the bestial, violent nature that civilization must hide away‚Äîliterally buried beneath the palace in a maze. The bull head symbolizes base instincts, rage, and masculine aggression, while the human body suggests these forces exist within humanity itself. The Labyrinth represents psychological complexity, the unconscious, and the difficulty of confronting our inner beast. The annual tribute of youths represents the cost of maintaining civilized order‚Äîthe sacrifice of innocence to appease the beast within. Theseus's victory represents consciousness penetrating the unconscious labyrinth to confront and slay the shadow self. Ariadne's thread symbolizes the guide (often feminine wisdom or love) needed to navigate inner complexity.
mythologyContexts.culturalSignificance: The Minotaur became a powerful symbol in Western culture of the beast within man, the price of hubris, and the hero's confrontation with the monstrous. The Labyrinth itself became a metaphor for psychological complexity and the journey inward. The myth may reflect historical Minoan practices of bull-worship and possible human sacrifice. The story influenced countless later tales of heroes confronting monsters in mazes. Picasso's series of Minotaur artworks explored themes of masculine violence and bestial desire. In psychology, the Minotaur represents the shadow self that must be confronted in the depths of the unconscious.
